title: Gerard Fraser
text:
Gerard Fraser (born 5 November 1978) in <a href="Rangiora">Rangiora</a>, <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> is a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player who currently plays at <a href="Fly-half%20%28rugby%20union%29">fly-half</a> for the <a href="Union%20Bordeaux%20B%C3%A8gles">Union Bordeaux Bègles</a> in the <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a>.
With stiff competition coming from the likes of <a href="Andrew%20Mehrtens">Andrew Mehrtens</a>, <a href="Aaron%20Mauger">Aaron Mauger</a> and <a href="Dan%20Carter">Dan Carter</a> for the <a href="Crusaders%20%28rugby%29">Crusaders</a>, he decided to go into exile in Europe where he started with the <a href="Italy">Italian</a> club <a href="Rugby%20Calvisano">Rugby Calvisano</a>.
He signed with Rugby Calvisano in 2002 where he played a vital part in their domestic title (<a href="Coppa%20Italia%20%28rugby%20union%29">Coppa Italia</a>) win in 2003 and also their winning of the <a href="Top12">Super 10</a> in 2005 & 2008.
From there he played two season for <a href="Aviron%20Bayonnais">Aviron Bayonnais</a> before moving to <a href="L%27Aquila%20Rugby">L'Aquila Rugby</a> in 2009, where he scored 160 points in 13 games (including 6 <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">tries</a>).
In April 2010, it was announced that he had signed to the French <a href="Rugby%20Pro%20D2">Pro D2</a> team, <a href="Union%20Bordeaux%20B%C3%A8gles">Union Bordeaux Bègles</a>. In the <a href="2010-11%20Rugby%20Pro%20D2%20season">2010-11 Rugby Pro D2 season</a>, he constantly remained in the top 5 point scorers in the competition reaching over 320 points as Bordeaux won promotion to the <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a>.
